body:
This is already possible via the `"browserify": { "transform": [ ".." ] }` field in your `package.json`.

[example](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim#packagejson)

If your transform needs more options, you can look them up from the relevant `package.json` whenever it transforms a file.

browserify-shim does this by [finding the first `package.json` searching upwards in the directory tree](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim/blob/ebd4e3966a189220c210bcca735fbb38c424c9e6/lib/resolve-shims.js#L113).

@thlorenz that is a good method of doing this, hadn't considered that. 

I still don't see an easy way of using this to disable module level transforms from other plugins that bundle using browserify (such as grunt-browserify or karma-browserify). Any suggestions on how to do that?

I suppose another concern would be that you are relying on the `package.json` file for this to happen. Perhaps I want to use different options in two different configs for grunt-browserify, I couldn't do this since my transform would just look to the same `package.json` for each.

Also, just to clarify, `browserify-shim` doesn't actually make any of the "options" stuff possible, it's just an example of a transform that gets its options from `package.json`.

@colinkahn I'm not sure why you would want to disable transforms. Either they are needed or not.

If you actually publish the generated code and therefore want to disable when you publish, I'd suggest using cli flags to specify these transforms while you are working on the module.

Current transforms have this simple signature: `function ({String} file) -> {TransformStream}`. This makes them highly compatible with other tools like [catw](https://github.com/substack/catw) and [mutiny](https://github.com/thlorenz/mutiny).
Changing that signature to allow options to be passed to a transform would undo this great compatibility

WRT grunt-browserify and other grunt tools. Since they decided to repeat all config options in the `Gruntfile`, which makes them inaccessible to other tools you will run into these kind of problems with them.
Adding options to the `package.json` is a common standard (`node`, `npm`, `browserify`, etc.) do it this way. It makes it easy for everyone to find and consume them.
So the fact that options are in the `package.json` is not the problem, but the fact that `grunt` decided to do things its own way actually is.

This shows with other tools as well, i.e. when adding `jshint` options to the `Gruntfile` while all other tools are looking for it in your `.jshintrc` in your project dir.

Sounds to me like that Ibrik tool is doing something weird. Am I understanding correctly that it stores the generated JavaScript in `.coffee` files?
If you can configure it to store JS in `.js` files it would fix your problem since `coffeeify` would skip those.

In this example Ibrik would be a transform (ibrikify or something), and from what I understand you can't change the file names while transforms are taking place. 

For example even when using coffeeify the file extensions don't change, so if you accidentally added coffeeify twice as a transform you'd get an error.

Ah, now I understand, so you have conflicting transforms.
So here is what you could do, create a transform that does the following:
- has Ibrik and coffeeify as deps
- has transform function signature `function (file) { ..}`
- returns coffeeify by default
- returns Ibrik if you are running tests (i.e. by looking for a `IBRIK_TESTS` environment var)

Then you add that transform to your transforms field instead of `coffeeify`.

Right, this is basically what @substack mentioned in his reply to my tweet. That's currently the only way to do this right now. I think a better alternative than environment variables could be built into browserify though, my current suggestion being able to add transform options (obviously).

@colinkahn I can see where you are coming from, but your case is somewhat of an edge case and environment vars are not bad.
Especially when having a kind of plugin architecture using env vars to communicate is the best way since it keeps things decoupled, i.e. `browserify` doesn't have to know about any options.

@thlorenz I hear you, and this is what I will have to do for now. I still see potential for having better ways of handling this though and perhaps enabling people to use transforms in different ways by having those options available. I'm just not 100% sure what the "better" solution is right now, but that' essentially why this thread exists.

@colinkahn What would be so bad about: `MYTRANSFORM_CONFIG=./theconfig.js`?

Then your transform could source it. The only downside is that when someone depends on your module that env var wouldn't be set when it is included in the bundle.
In that case you'll have to use the strategy I used in browserify-shim.

However with [find-parent-dir](https://github.com/thlorenz/find-parent-dir) finding a config inside of the `package.json` of the enclosing package becomes a one liner.

Instead of

```
b.transform("transformify", {someOption: true})
```

you can do

```
b.transform(makeTransformify({someOption: true}))
```

where `makeTransformify` is a function which returns a `transformify` transform.

I guess the same you can do with `grunt-browserify`.
@andreypopp that's a really good suggestion. I guess then you'd just need a way to ignore module level transforms so their settings don't conflict.
@colinkahn I still don't understand why you want to ignore some transforms â€” if you don't want them to execute just leave them off the browserify configuration...
@andreypopp it's because sometimes you need them in there so when you require in your module into a project that project knows what transforms to apply.

@thlorenz yeah I think at this point I'm leaning away from formatting the transform field differently. I could see an almost workable version of this using the suggestions so far:
1. Transforms include an optional "makeTransform" function that will return the transform function with options set in a closure (used when adding the transform through the api)
2. If an option isn't set then the transform will look to it's parent `package.json` file for that option

Then all you'd need to add is some way to optionally ignore the transforms in `package.json` if you are doing something where the transforms you're setting through the api could conflict. That could be as simple as another option when you instantiate browerify or even an environment variable like `BROWSERIFY_IGNORE_PACKAGE_TRANSFORMS`.
@andreypopp not sure how that would allow passing options when depending on a package that uses that transform, since the option gets hardcoded into `_transform_this.js`.
@thlorenz how the `"transform-options"` field in `package.json` would allow that?

@colinkahn yep, I did something similar [for es6ify](https://github.com/thlorenz/es6ify/blob/master/index.js#L85) to allow overriding the `filepattern` of `es6` files.
That option always works.

The hard part is to allow configuring at transform of a dependency since that will just be invoked by browserify instead of your script. Again I think the approach taken with `browserify-shim` is pretty simple for that.
It wouldn't have to resolve config from `package.json` either, but could look for any other config file named by convention, i.e. `.ngtemplatefyrc`.
@andreypopp yep, got me there. You can't do that in either of our suggestions :(

@thlorenz yeah `package.json` would always be what is used when transforming a dependency, but having the convention where you use a `makeTransform` function to override the `package.json` options would give you complete control when using the api. And then yeah, you could set it up to use a different file to, if you had a reason not to use `package.json` for some reason. That would all be left to the transform developer. 

I still see the need though to allow shutting off transforms defined in `package.json`, otherwise you cannot uniquely configure a bundle using just the browserify api (since it will go back and just run the transforms in `package.json` at the end).

While we're on the subject of transform reform, I notice that there are many transforms based on Falafel.  If you have a bunch of these in your transform chain, then for each js file in your project, you end up reparsing the same file with Falafel over and over again.  It seems like there must be a more efficient way to do this.  It's tempting to write a "falafelify" transform that loads up a bunch of other transforms and runs them on every node, except how would I configure the transform list?  (See how I tied that back in?  Eh?  Eh?  :) )

I wouldn't want to go over the top with the possibilities.
Just set your env variable names accordingly, i.e. `module-foo-dev`, `module-bar-prod` so they don't pick up each others transforms, unless you desire it to do so.

You may even want sometimes to affect dependency transforms with a global env var, so in that case that behavior is even useful.

Everything else like the `module` confusing can quickly get confusing.

In summary picking good names for your config will work perfectly. In most cases none of the names will be present and only the transforms in the `browserify.transform` field will be used. The `config-transform` however in that case will find no matching config and just pass the content through.

@thlorenz that does make creating a templates for new components / projects more complex (IE, I can't use "prod" for each, I have to namespace it), but I do understand how this could make the transform itself more complex.

I still feel like it might be good to have some sort of "default" key in the `config-transform`. Consider the case where I do want to apply a transform when my module is required but I don't want that transform to happen when I'm using one of the other  modes enabled by an environment variable. The current setup would always run transforms in the transforms array before those in the other configurations, correct?
